questions.text: Concept of “Anatomical Position” is very essential for all kind of operative procedure and to understand and publish the articles. About anatomical position, which of the following statements is true?

options.label: A
options.text: The Palms of the Hands are facing Posteriorly.

options.label: C
options.text: The Feet are dorsiflexed at the ankles.

questions.correct_answer: B. The Thumb’s are oriented laterally.
questions.explanation:
Ans.  B) The Thumbs are oriented Laterally.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. The palms of the hands are facing anteriorly , not posteriorly. This allows for a clear view of the anatomical structures of the body.
  • • Option A.
  • • palms of the hands
  • • facing anteriorly
  • • allows
  • • clear view
  • • Option C. The feet are not dorsiflexed at the ankles in the anatomical position. Instead, they are in a neutral position , with the toes pointing forward .
  • • Option C.
  • • neutral position
  • • toes pointing forward
  • • Option D. The elbows are not fully flexed; they are extended in the anatomical position. This extension allows for accurate descriptions of the upper limb’s anatomical relationships .
  • • Option D.
  • • extended
  • • accurate descriptions
  • • upper limb’s anatomical relationships

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the anatomical position, the thumbs are oriented laterally . This position serves as a standardized reference for describing the location and orientation of anatomical structures in the human body.
  • ➤ thumbs
  • ➤ oriented laterally
  • ➤ standardized reference
  • ➤ location
  • ➤ orientation
  • ➤ anatomical structures
  • ➤ Ref: BD Chaurasia’s Handbook of General Anatomy, 7 th edition, Page no- 11, 12
  • ➤ Ref:
  • ➤ BD Chaurasia’s Handbook of General Anatomy, 7 th edition, Page no- 11, 12

questions.text: Which of the following describes the movements known as pronation and supination?

options.label: A
options.text: The Flexing of the arm with respect to the Forearm around the Elbow.

options.label: B
options.text: The Swivelling of the foot to the Medial and Lateral Directions.

options.label: C
options.text: The Downward & Upward rotation of Hand when Elbow is Semi Flexed.

options.label: D
options.text: The Rotation at the shoulder that causes the arm to describe a Cone Shape.

questions.correct_answer: C. The Downward & Upward rotation of Hand when Elbow is Semi Flexed.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) The Downward & Upward rotation of Hand when Elbow is Semi Flexed.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. The Flexing of the Arm with Respect to the Forearm around the Elbow : This describes flexion and extension , not pronation or supination. Flexion refers to decreasing the angle between the forearm and arm , while extension is increasing this angle .
  • • Option A. The Flexing of the Arm with Respect to the Forearm around the Elbow
  • • flexion
  • • extension
  • • Flexion
  • • decreasing
  • • angle
  • • forearm
  • • arm
  • • extension
  • • increasing
  • • angle
  • • Option B. The Swivelling of the Foot to the Medial and Lateral Directions : This is describing inversion and eversion of the foot . Inversion involves turning the sole of the foot inward , while eversion is turning it outward . These movements occur at the ankle and subtalar joints .
  • • Option B. The Swivelling of the Foot to the Medial and Lateral Directions
  • • inversion
  • • eversion
  • • foot
  • • turning
  • • sole
  • • foot inward
  • • eversion
  • • turning
  • • outward
  • • ankle
  • • subtalar joints
  • • Option D. The Rotation at the Shoulder that Causes the Arm to Describe a Cone Shape : This is describing circumduction , a circular movement of the limb that combines flexion , extension, abduction , and adduction . It is not specific to pronation or supination.
  • • Option D. The Rotation at the Shoulder that Causes the Arm to Describe a Cone Shape
  • • circumduction
  • • circular movement
  • • limb
  • • combines flexion
  • • extension, abduction
  • • adduction

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The Twisting of the Wrist While the Elbow is Held Motionless : This correctly describes pronation and supination. These movements occur primarily at the radioulnar joint . In pronation , the radius rotates over the ulna so the palm faces downward . In supination , the radius and ulna are parallel , and the palm faces upward .
  • ➤ The Twisting of the Wrist While the Elbow is Held Motionless
  • ➤ primarily
  • ➤ radioulnar joint
  • ➤ pronation
  • ➤ radius
  • ➤ rotates over the ulna
  • ➤ palm
  • ➤ downward
  • ➤ supination
  • ➤ radius
  • ➤ ulna are parallel
  • ➤ palm faces upward
  • ➤ Ref: Textbook of Upper limb and Thorax, 3 rd Edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 134
  • ➤ Ref: Textbook of Upper limb and Thorax, 3 rd Edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 134

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents to the primary care clinic with complaints of facial pain and pressure, a persistent low-grade fever, and nasal congestion for the past two weeks. He also mentions postnasal drip and a reduced sense of smell. He denies any recent upper respiratory tract infections, but he recalls having similar symptoms in the past during allergy seasons. This clinical case is associated with which of the following pair of bone and its type?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Ethmoid

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Option A. Mandible is a flat bone of lower jaw and is not considered a pneumatic bone.
  • • Option A.
  • • lower jaw
  • • Option B. Occipital is a flat bone of does not contain pneumatic cells.
  • • Option B.
  • • does not
  • • Option C. Vertebrae are the bones of the spine and do not typically contain pneumatic cells.
  • • Option C.
  • • spine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The ethmoid bone is classified as a pneumatic bone due to the presence of ethmoidal air cells .
  • ➤ presence of ethmoidal air cells
  • ➤ Ref: Textbook of General Anatomy, 3 rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 69
  • ➤ Ref: Textbook of General Anatomy, 3 rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 69

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents with anterior knee pain that worsens with activities like running and jumping. On physical examination, there is tenderness and swelling over the front of the knee. Palpation reveals a small, round, bony prominence at the centre of the knee. The patient reports no recent trauma. You will put the involved bone in which of the following type?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Sesamoid

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Sphenoid –
  • • Option A. Sphenoid
  • • It is a complex bone located at the base of the skull , in the middle of the cranial floor . It is not embedded within a tendon.
  • • It is a complex bone located at the base of the skull , in the middle of the cranial floor .
  • • complex bone
  • • base of the skull
  • • middle
  • • cranial floor
  • • It is not embedded within a tendon.
  • • Option B. Hyoid –
  • • Option B. Hyoid
  • • U-shaped bone located in the anterior neck that does not directly articulate with any other bone. It serves as an anchoring structure for the tongue and muscles in the neck and throat but is not embedded within a tendon.
  • • U-shaped bone located in the anterior neck that does not directly articulate with any other bone.
  • • U-shaped bone
  • • anterior neck
  • • It serves as an anchoring structure for the tongue and muscles in the neck and throat but is not embedded within a tendon.
  • • anchoring structure
  • • tongue
  • • muscles
  • • neck
  • • throat
  • • Option C. Ethmoid –
  • • Option C. Ethmoid
  • • It is located between the eyes and at the roof of the nasal cavity . It is part of the cranial floor and contributes to the medial wall of the orbit , the nasal septum , and the nasal cavity .
  • • It is located between the eyes and at the roof of the nasal cavity .
  • • eyes
  • • roof of the nasal cavity
  • • It is part of the cranial floor and contributes to the medial wall of the orbit , the nasal septum , and the nasal cavity .
  • • cranial floor
  • • medial wall
  • • orbit
  • • nasal septum
  • • nasal cavity

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Sesamoid : Sesamoid bones like patella are small, round bones that are embedded within tendons . They are found in locations where a tendon passes over a joint , such as the knee, hand, and foot. It helps to overcome compressive forces and modify pressure , reduce friction , and occasionally alter the direction of muscle pull .
  • ➤ Sesamoid
  • ➤ small, round bones
  • ➤ embedded within tendons
  • ➤ tendon passes over a joint
  • ➤ overcome compressive forces
  • ➤ modify pressure
  • ➤ reduce friction
  • ➤ occasionally
  • ➤ direction of muscle pull
  • ➤ Ref: T extbook of General Anatomy, 2 nd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 69
  • ➤ Ref: T extbook of General Anatomy, 2 nd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 69

questions.text: Which of the following bone of the skull articulates to form a synovial joint?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) The Mandible

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. The Sphenoid
  • • Option A.
  • • The Sphenoid
  • • It is a complex bone located at the base of the skull , forming part of the cranial floor. It does not form a synovial joint; rather, it articulates with other cranial bones through sutures .
  • • It is a complex bone located at the base of the skull , forming part of the cranial floor.
  • • complex bone
  • • base of the skull
  • • It does not form a synovial joint; rather, it articulates with other cranial bones through sutures .
  • • through sutures
  • • Option B. The Maxilla
  • • Option B. The Maxilla
  • • It forms the upper jaw and is involved in forming the roof of the mouth, floors of the orbits , and sides and floor of the nasal cavity . The maxilla is fused to other bones of the face and does not form a synovial joint.
  • • It forms the upper jaw and is involved in forming the roof of the mouth, floors of the orbits , and sides and floor of the nasal cavity .
  • • upper jaw
  • • forming the roof
  • • floors
  • • orbits
  • • sides
  • • floor of the nasal cavity
  • • The maxilla is fused to other bones of the face and does not form a synovial joint.
  • • Option D. The Hyoid
  • • Option D. The Hyoid
  • • It is a U-shaped bone in the neck that supports the tongue and provides attachment for muscles associated with swallowing . It is not directly attached to other bones but is suspended by ligaments and muscles . The hyoid does not form a synovial joint.
  • • It is a U-shaped bone in the neck that supports the tongue and provides attachment for muscles associated with swallowing .
  • • U-shaped bone
  • • neck
  • • supports
  • • tongue
  • • swallowing
  • • It is not directly attached to other bones but is suspended by ligaments and muscles .
  • • suspended
  • • ligaments and muscles
  • • The hyoid does not form a synovial joint.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Mandible or lower jawbone , forms a synovial joint with the temporal bone of the skull known as the Temporo-Mandibular Joint (TMJ) . It is a hinge type of synovial joint that allows for the movement necessary for chewing, speaking , and other mouth movements.
  • ➤ The Mandible
  • ➤ lower jawbone
  • ➤ synovial joint
  • ➤ temporal bone
  • ➤ Temporo-Mandibular Joint (TMJ)
  • ➤ hinge
  • ➤ chewing, speaking
  • ➤ Ref: Textbook of Anatomy regional and clinical head, 2 nd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 17
  • ➤ Ref: Textbook of Anatomy regional and clinical head, 2 nd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 17

questions.text: A 28-year-old patient presents with a painful, swollen finger after accidentally slamming it in a door. On examination, there is tenderness and deformity of the proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joint. Which bone of the hand is most likely to be fractured in this scenario?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Phalanges

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Short Bones:-
  • • Option A. Short Bones:-
  • • They are defined by their cuboidal shape and are primarily found in the wrist and ankle . They are not the bones of the fingers.
  • • They are defined by their cuboidal shape and are primarily found in the wrist and ankle .
  • • cuboidal shape
  • • wrist
  • • ankle
  • • They are not the bones of the fingers.
  • • Option B. Metacarpals
  • • Option B. Metacarpals
  • • They are the five long bones located in the hand between the carpal bones and the fingers. Each metacarpal corresponds to a digit of the hand, but they are not the bones within the fingers themselves.
  • • They are the five long bones located in the hand between the carpal bones and the fingers.
  • • five long bones
  • • hand
  • • Each metacarpal corresponds to a digit of the hand, but they are not the bones within the fingers themselves.
  • • corresponds
  • • digit
  • • Option C. Carpals
  • • Option C.
  • • Carpals
  • • They are the eight small bones that make up the wrist, connecting the hand to the forearm . They are arranged in two rows and contribute to the wrist's complex range of movements . However, they are not the bones of the fingers.
  • • They are the eight small bones that make up the wrist, connecting the hand to the forearm .
  • • eight small bones
  • • connecting
  • • hand
  • • forearm
  • • They are arranged in two rows and contribute to the wrist's complex range of movements . However, they are not the bones of the fingers.
  • • two rows
  • • wrist's complex range
  • • movements

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Phalanges :
  • ➤ Phalanges
  • ➤ They are the bones of the fingers ( and toes ). Each finger has three phalanges - the proximal , middle , and distal phalanges , except for the thumb , which has only two (proximal and distal) . These bones provide the structural framework of the fingers , allowing for their extensive range of motion and dexterity.
  • ➤ They are the bones of the fingers ( and toes ).
  • ➤ bones of the fingers
  • ➤ and toes
  • ➤ Each finger has three phalanges - the proximal , middle , and distal phalanges , except for the thumb , which has only two (proximal and distal) .
  • ➤ three phalanges
  • ➤ proximal
  • ➤ middle
  • ➤ distal phalanges
  • ➤ except
  • ➤ thumb
  • ➤ only two (proximal and distal)
  • ➤ These bones provide the structural framework of the fingers , allowing for their extensive range of motion and dexterity.
  • ➤ structural framework
  • ➤ fingers
  • ➤ extensive range of motion and dexterity.
  • ➤ Ref: Textbook of General Anatomy, 2 nd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 69
  • ➤ Ref: Textbook of General Anatomy, 2 nd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 69

questions.text: Which of the following lists comprises bones that are part of the appendicular skeleton?
questions.correct_answer: B. Clavicle, Fibula, Metatarsal, Phalange, Radius
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Clavicle, Fibula,  Metatarsal, Phalange, Radius

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Patella, Ethmoid, Femur, Coccyx, Tibia
  • • Option A. Patella, Ethmoid, Femur, Coccyx, Tibia
  • • Patella (Kneecap) is part of the appendicular skeleton . Ethmoid is a cranial bone, part of the axial skeleton . Femur (Thigh bone) is part of the appendicular skeleton . Coccyx (Tailbone) is part of the axial skeleton . Tibia (Shinbone) is part of the appendicular skeleton . This list contains bones from both the axial and appendicular skeletons .
  • • Patella (Kneecap) is part of the appendicular skeleton .
  • • Patella
  • • appendicular skeleton
  • • Ethmoid is a cranial bone, part of the axial skeleton .
  • • Ethmoid
  • • axial skeleton
  • • Femur (Thigh bone) is part of the appendicular skeleton .
  • • Femur
  • • appendicular skeleton
  • • Coccyx (Tailbone) is part of the axial skeleton .
  • • Coccyx
  • • axial skeleton
  • • Tibia (Shinbone) is part of the appendicular skeleton .
  • • Tibia
  • • appendicular skeleton
  • • This list contains bones from both the axial and appendicular skeletons .
  • • both
  • • axial
  • • appendicular skeletons
  • • Option C. Humerus, Scapula, Occipital, Metacarpal, Sternum
  • • Option C. Humerus, Scapula, Occipital, Metacarpal, Sternum
  • • Humerus (Upper Arm Bone) is part of the appendicular skeleton . Scapula (Shoulder Blade) is part of the appendicular skeleton . Occipital is a cranial bone, part of the axial skeleton . Metacarpals are the bones in the hand, part of the appendicular skeleton . Sternum (Breastbone) is part of the axial skeleton . This list contains bones from both the axial and appendicular skeletons .
  • • Humerus (Upper Arm Bone) is part of the appendicular skeleton .

  • • Occipital

  • • Metacarpals
  • • appendicular skeleton

  • • Sternum
  • • axial skeleton
  • • This list contains bones from both the axial and appendicular skeletons .

  • • appendicular skeletons
  • • Option D. Ulna, Radius, Phalanges, Mandible, Coxal
  • • Option D. Ulna, Radius, Phalanges, Mandible, Coxal
  • • Ulna is a bone in the forearm, part of the appendicular skeleton . Radius is a bone in the forearm, part of the appendicular skeleton . Phalanges are the finger and toe bones, part of the appendicular skeleton . Mandible (Lower Jawbone) is part of the axial skeleton . Coxal (Hip Bone) is part of the pelvic girdle of the appendicular skeleton .

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Skeleton system can be divided into 2 following parts: Axial Skeleton Appendicular Skeleton Clavicle (Collar bone/ beauty bone) is part of pectoral girdle ( Appendicular System ) Fibula is postaxial bone of lower limb ( Appendicular System ) Metatarsal are the bones in the foot, part of the Appendicular Skeleton . Phalange are the bones in the hand & foot, part of the Appendicular Skeleton . Radius is preaxial bone of forearm ( Appendicular System )

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with complaints of joint pain, swelling, and limited range of motion in the knee joint. Physical examination reveals warmth and tenderness around the affected joint, and imaging studies show joint space narrowing and bone erosion. Which of the following category of joint is most likely associated with this patient's condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Freely Moveable Joint

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Synarthrosis (Fibrous Joint):
  • • Option A. Synarthrosis (Fibrous Joint):
  • • They are a type of joint where the bones are tightly connected and no movement. An example of a synarthrosis is the sutures of the skull . Synarthroses are the opposite of synovial joints , as they allow no movement.
  • • They are a type of joint where the bones are tightly connected and no movement.
  • • bones
  • • tightly connected
  • • An example of a synarthrosis is the sutures of the skull .
  • • synarthrosis
  • • sutures
  • • skull
  • • Synarthroses are the opposite of synovial joints , as they allow no movement.
  • • opposite
  • • synovial joints
  • • Option B. Slightly Movable Joint:
  • • Option B. Slightly Movable Joint:
  • • These joints are also known as amphiarthosis . It allows a small amount of movement, usually because the bones are connected by cartilage . An example is the joints between the vertebrae of the spine. While slightly moveable joints do allow some movement , they do not offer the range of motion seen in synovial joints.
  • • These joints are also known as amphiarthosis .
  • • amphiarthosis
  • • It allows a small amount of movement, usually because the bones are connected by cartilage .
  • • bones
  • • connected by cartilage
  • • An example is the joints between the vertebrae of the spine.
  • • While slightly moveable joints do allow some movement , they do not offer the range of motion seen in synovial joints.
  • • do allow some movement

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Freely Moveable Joint:
  • ➤ Freely Moveable Joint:
  • ➤ It allows a wide range of movement . Examples include the knee, hip, shoulder, and elbow . They are characterized by a synovial cavity filled with synovial fluid , which facilitates movement .
  • ➤ It allows a wide range of movement . Examples include the knee, hip, shoulder, and elbow .
  • ➤ wide range of movement
  • ➤ knee, hip, shoulder, and elbow
  • ➤ They are characterized by a synovial cavity filled with synovial fluid , which facilitates movement .
  • ➤ synovial cavity
  • ➤ synovial fluid
  • ➤ facilitates movement
  • ➤ Ref: Textbook of General Anatomy, 3 rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 88
  • ➤ Ref: Textbook of General Anatomy, 3 rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 88

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with unexplained fatigue and pallor. Laboratory tests reveal low hemoglobin levels and a decreased red blood cell count. Further evaluation shows a decrease in erythrocyte production in the bone marrow. Which of the following is most likely the content of the medullary canal of a long bone responsible for erythropoiesis in adults?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Marrow

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Trabeculae:
  • • Option A. Trabeculae:
  • • Trabeculae are the small, needle-like pieces of bone that provide structural support within spongy bone. They are primarily found in the ends of long bones (epiphyses) and within the interior of other bones, not typically within the medullary canal.
  • • Trabeculae are the small, needle-like pieces of bone that provide structural support within spongy bone.
  • • They are primarily found in the ends of long bones (epiphyses) and within the interior of other bones, not typically within the medullary canal.
  • • Option B. Lamellae:
  • • Option B. Lamellae:
  • • They are thin layers of bone tissue that make up the concentric rings in compact bone. They are a part of the osteon or Haversian system, which is the structural unit of compact bone.
  • • They are thin layers of bone tissue that make up the concentric rings in compact bone.
  • • They are a part of the osteon or Haversian system, which is the structural unit of compact bone.
  • • Option D. Osteoblasts and Osteoclasts:
  • • Option D. Osteoblasts and Osteoclasts:
  • • Osteoblasts are cells that form new bone tissue, and osteoclasts are cells that break down old bone tissue. These cells are found throughout the bone, particularly in areas of bone remodeling.
  • • Osteoblasts are cells that form new bone tissue, and osteoclasts are cells that break down old bone tissue.
  • • These cells are found throughout the bone, particularly in areas of bone remodeling.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Marrow –
  • ➤ Marrow –
  • ➤ It is a soft, fatty tissue found inside the medullary canal. There are two types of bone marrow: Red marrow, which is involved in blood cell production Yellow marrow, which primarily stores fat.
  • ➤ It is a soft, fatty tissue found inside the medullary canal.
  • ➤ There are two types of bone marrow: Red marrow, which is involved in blood cell production Yellow marrow, which primarily stores fat.
  • ➤ Red marrow, which is involved in blood cell production Yellow marrow, which primarily stores fat.
  • ➤ Red marrow, which is involved in blood cell production
  • ➤ Yellow marrow, which primarily stores fat.
  • ➤ Ref: Textbook of General Anatomy, 3 rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 73
  • ➤ Ref:
  • ➤ Textbook of General Anatomy, 3 rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 73

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient presents with a suspected fracture of the tibia. On imaging studies, blood vessels located within the compact bone are most critical for providing nourishment to the deeper regions of the bone? Where are these blood vessels located within compact bone?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) In the Central Canal

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A . In the Canaliculi :
  • • Option A
  • • In the Canaliculi
  • • Blood vessels are not typically found in the canaliculi of compact bone. Canaliculi are tiny channels or tunnels that allow for the exchange of nutrients and waste products between osteocytes and blood vessels . While they facilitate communication between cells and nearby blood vessels, the blood vessels themselves are not located within the canaliculi.
  • • Blood vessels are not typically found in the canaliculi of compact bone.
  • • Canaliculi are tiny channels or tunnels that allow for the exchange of nutrients and waste products between osteocytes and blood vessels .
  • • Canaliculi
  • • tiny channels
  • • tunnels
  • • exchange of nutrients
  • • waste products
  • • osteocytes
  • • blood vessels
  • • While they facilitate communication between cells and nearby blood vessels, the blood vessels themselves are not located within the canaliculi.
  • • facilitate communication
  • • Option B . In the Periosteum :
  • • Option B
  • • In the Periosteum
  • • Blood vessels are indeed found in the periosteum. The periosteum is a dense connective tissue membrane that covers the outer surface of bones and contains blood vessels, nerves , and other structures .
  • • Blood vessels are indeed found in the periosteum.
  • • The periosteum is a dense connective tissue membrane that covers the outer surface of bones and contains blood vessels, nerves , and other structures .
  • • periosteum
  • • dense connective tissue membrane
  • • outer surface
  • • bones
  • • blood vessels, nerves
  • • other structures
  • • Option C. In the Lacunae :
  • • Option C.
  • • In the Lacunae
  • • Blood vessels are not typically found within the lacunae. Lacunae are small spaces within the bone matrix where osteocytes reside . These spaces house bone cells but not blood vessels.
  • • Blood vessels are not typically found within the lacunae.
  • • Lacunae are small spaces within the bone matrix where osteocytes reside .
  • • small spaces
  • • bone matrix
  • • osteocytes reside
  • • These spaces house bone cells but not blood vessels.
  • • house bone cells

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Blood vessels are primarily found in the central canal , also known as the Haversian canal or osteonic canal . The central canal runs longitudinally through the center of each osteon and contains blood vessels , nerves , and connective tissue .

questions.text: In the context of young bones, which part is primarily responsible for longitudinal growth?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Metaphysis.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Diaphysis
  • • Option A. Diaphysis
  • • Part of bone which ossify from primary centre of ossification known as diaphysis. It is the central shaft of a long bone and is not primarily responsible for longitudinal growth.
  • • Part of bone which ossify from primary centre of ossification known as diaphysis.
  • • ossify from primary centre
  • • It is the central shaft of a long bone and is not primarily responsible for longitudinal growth.
  • • central shaft
  • • Option B. Epiphysis
  • • Option B. Epiphysis
  • • Part of bone which ossify from secondary centre of ossification known as epiphysis. It refers to the ends of the long bone, and while it plays a role in joint function and stability , it is not the primary site for longitudinal growth.
  • • Part of bone which ossify from secondary centre of ossification known as epiphysis.
  • • ossify from secondary centre
  • • It refers to the ends of the long bone, and while it plays a role in joint function and stability , it is not the primary site for longitudinal growth.
  • • joint function
  • • stability
  • • Option D. Periosteum
  • • Option D. Periosteum
  • • It is a dense fibrous membrane that covers the outer surface of bones. While it is important for bone development and repair , it is not directly involved in longitudinal growth.
  • • It is a dense fibrous membrane that covers the outer surface of bones.
  • • dense fibrous membrane
  • • While it is important for bone development and repair , it is not directly involved in longitudinal growth.
  • • important for bone development and repair

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In young bones, the part primarily responsible for longitudinal growth is the metaphysis , which houses the epiphyseal plate (growth plate).
  • ➤ In young bones, the part primarily responsible for longitudinal growth is the metaphysis , which houses the epiphyseal plate (growth plate).
  • ➤ part primarily responsible
  • ➤ longitudinal growth
  • ➤ metaphysis

  • ➤ Ref: Textbook of General Anatomy, 3 rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 74

questions.text: Where is the epiphyseal plate of a long bone located?

options.label: B
options.text: Between the Diaphysis and the Epiphysis

questions.correct_answer: B. Between the Diaphysis and the Epiphysis
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Between the Diaphysis and the Epiphysis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Option A. In the Diaphysis: It is the shaft or central part of a long bone . The epiphyseal plate is not located within the diaphysis. Instead, the diaphysis is primarily composed of compact bone and contains the medullary cavity .
  • • Option A. In the Diaphysis:
  • • shaft
  • • central part
  • • long bone
  • • diaphysis
  • • primarily composed
  • • compact bone
  • • contains the medullary cavity
  • • Option C. In the Epiphysis: The epiphysis refers to the rounded end of a long bone . While the epiphyseal plate is adjacent to the epiphysis , it is not located within the epiphysis itself. The epiphysis is primarily made of spongy bone and contributes to joint formation .
  • • Option C. In the Epiphysis:
  • • rounded end
  • • long bone
  • • adjacent
  • • epiphysis
  • • primarily made
  • • spongy bone
  • • contributes to joint formation
  • • Option D. In the Medullary Canal: The medullary canal , or medullary cavity , is the central cavity of bone shafts where red and yellow bone marrow is stored .
  • • Option D. In the Medullary Canal:
  • • medullary canal
  • • medullary cavity
  • • central cavity
  • • bone shafts
  • • red and yellow bone marrow
  • • stored

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Between the Diaphysis and the Epiphysis: The epiphyseal plate is the area of growing tissue near the ends of the long bones. It is located between the diaphysis and the epiphysis of the bone. The plate is responsible for longitudinal growth of the bone, as new bone is added at this location during development.
  • ➤ Between the Diaphysis and the Epiphysis:
  • ➤ area of growing tissue
  • ➤ diaphysis
  • ➤ epiphysis
  • ➤ responsible
  • ➤ longitudinal growth
  • ➤ Ref: Textbook of General Anatomy, 3 rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 72
  • ➤ Ref: Textbook of General Anatomy, 3 rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 72

questions.text: Match the correct pair:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 1- b, 2-a, 3-d, 4-c

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • 1. Pressure Epiphysis:
  • • 1. Pressure Epiphysis:
  • • Pressure epiphyses are regions of long bones where growth occurs due to the pressure applied to the epiphyseal plate . Growth is a result of compression forces . Example: The distal end of the femur is a pressure epiphysis . During childhood and adolescence , the weight-bearing activities apply pressure on this epiphysis, allowing for bone elongation .
  • • Pressure epiphyses are regions of long bones where growth occurs due to the pressure applied to the epiphyseal plate .
  • • long bones
  • • growth
  • • pressure
  • • epiphyseal plate
  • • Growth is a result of compression forces .
  • • Growth
  • • compression forces
  • • Example: The distal end of the femur is a pressure epiphysis .
  • • Example:
  • • distal end
  • • pressure epiphysis
  • • During childhood and adolescence , the weight-bearing activities apply pressure on this epiphysis, allowing for bone elongation .
  • • During childhood
  • • adolescence
  • • weight-bearing activities
  • • pressure
  • • allowing
  • • bone elongation
  • • 2. Traction Epiphysis:
  • • 2. Traction Epiphysis:
  • • Traction epiphyses are areas in long bones where growth happens in response to pulling or traction forces on the epiphyseal plate . These forces are typically exerted by tendons or muscles attached to the bone. Example: The proximal end of the tibia is a traction epiphysis . The action of the patellar tendon , connected to the tibial tuberosity , leads to traction forces that promote bone growth .
  • • Traction epiphyses are areas in long bones where growth happens in response to pulling or traction forces on the epiphyseal plate .
  • • growth happens
  • • response
  • • pulling
  • • traction forces
  • • epiphyseal plate
  • • These forces are typically exerted by tendons or muscles attached to the bone.
  • • typically exerted
  • • tendons
  • • muscles
  • • Example: The proximal end of the tibia is a traction epiphysis .
  • • Example:
  • • proximal end
  • • traction epiphysis
  • • The action of the patellar tendon , connected to the tibial tuberosity , leads to traction forces that promote bone growth .
  • • action
  • • patellar tendon
  • • tibial tuberosity
  • • traction forces
  • • promote bone growth
  • • 3. Atavistic Epiphysis:
  • • 3. Atavistic Epiphysis:
  • • Atavistic epiphyses are secondary centers of ossification that are rare and may resemble ancestral bone structures . They are considered vestigial . Example: The presence of an additional epiphysis in the elbow joint that is not typically seen in modern humans would be considered an atavistic epiphysis.
  • • Atavistic epiphyses are secondary centers of ossification that are rare and may resemble ancestral bone structures .
  • • secondary centers of ossification
  • • rare
  • • resemble ancestral bone structures
  • • They are considered vestigial .
  • • vestigial
  • • Example: The presence of an additional epiphysis in the elbow joint that is not typically seen in modern humans would be considered an atavistic epiphysis.
  • • Example:
  • • epiphysis
  • • elbow joint
  • • 4. Aberrant Epiphysis:
  • • 4. Aberrant Epiphysis:
  • • Aberrant epiphyses are anomalous growth centers or irregularities in bone development that deviate from the usual patterns. Example: An individual with an extra epiphyseal center in the metacarpal bone , not commonly observed in the general population, would have an aberrant epiphysis.
  • • Aberrant epiphyses are anomalous growth centers or irregularities in bone development that deviate from the usual patterns.
  • • anomalous growth centers
  • • irregularities
  • • bone development
  • • deviate
  • • Example: An individual with an extra epiphyseal center in the metacarpal bone , not commonly observed in the general population, would have an aberrant epiphysis.
  • • Example:
  • • extra epiphyseal center
  • • metacarpal bone

questions.text: In which structure osteoclasts and osteoblasts are found?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) In the Periosteum

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. In the Haversian Canals: Haversian canals are a series of tubes around narrow channels formed by lamellae , found in the osteon of compact bone . While Haversian canals contain blood vessels and nerves , they are not the primary location for osteoblasts and osteoclasts.
  • • Option B. In the Haversian Canals:
  • • series of tubes
  • • narrow channels
  • • lamellae
  • • osteon of compact bone
  • • blood vessels
  • • nerves
  • • Option C. In the Lacunae of Osteons: Lacunae are small spaces within the osteon that contain osteocytes , which are mature bone cells . Osteoclasts and osteoblasts are not typically found in the lacunae. The lacunae primarily house osteocytes .
  • • Option C. In the Lacunae of Osteons:
  • • small spaces within
  • • osteon
  • • osteocytes
  • • mature bone cells
  • • lacunae primarily house osteocytes
  • • Option D. In the Trabeculae of Osteons: They are the spongy parts of bone that provide structural support and are found in the interior of bones . While trabeculae are involved in the bone remodeling process , osteoclasts and osteoblasts are more active in the periosteum and endosteum than within the trabeculae themselves.
  • • Option D. In the Trabeculae of Osteons:
  • • spongy parts of bone
  • • structural support
  • • found
  • • interior of bones
  • • involved
  • • bone remodeling process
  • • osteoclasts
  • • osteoblasts
  • • more active
  • • periosteum
  • • endosteum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The periosteum is a dense layer of vascular connective tissue enveloping the bones except at the surfaces of the joints . Both osteoblasts and osteoclasts are found in the periosteum . This layer is crucial for bone growth and repair , as these cells are actively involved in bone remodelling .
  • ➤ dense layer
  • ➤ vascular connective tissue
  • ➤ bones
  • ➤ except
  • ➤ surfaces of the joints
  • ➤ Both osteoblasts
  • ➤ osteoclasts
  • ➤ periosteum
  • ➤ crucial
  • ➤ bone growth
  • ➤ repair
  • ➤ bone remodelling
  • ➤ Ref: Textbook of General Anatomy, 3 rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 71
  • ➤ Ref: Textbook of General Anatomy, 3 rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 71

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presents with chronic hip pain. On X-ray, you observe a bony projection extending from the femoral neck. There are several normal projections from bone which can mimic such clinical situation. Among these which of the following is NOT a projection from a bone surface?
A 21-years-old patient Suyash came to OPD with history of fall on hand. Now he is having pain at hand region. X ray of patient is given. Which of the following joint has been shown in his X-ray?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Ellipsoid Joint.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Hinge Joints, such as the elbow joint, primarily allow for flexion and extension movements in one plane .
  • • Option A.
  • • allow for flexion
  • • extension movements
  • • one plane
  • • Option B. Ball-and-Socket Joints, like the hip joint, allow for a wide range of motion , including flexion, extension, abduction, adduction, and rotation .
  • • Option B.
  • • allow
  • • wide range of motion
  • • including flexion, extension, abduction, adduction,
  • • rotation
  • • Option D. Saddle Joints, such as the carpometacarpal joint of the thumb, allow for movements in multiple directions , including flexion, extension, abduction, adduction , and circumduction .
  • • Option D.
  • • allow
  • • movements
  • • multiple directions
  • • flexion, extension, abduction, adduction
  • • circumduction

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Wrist joint ( radiocarpal joint ) is classified as an ellipsoid joint , primarily allowing flexion , extension , and side-to-side movements without axial rotation.
  • ➤ Wrist joint ( radiocarpal joint ) is classified as an ellipsoid joint , primarily allowing flexion , extension , and side-to-side movements without axial rotation.
  • ➤ Wrist joint
  • ➤ radiocarpal joint
  • ➤ ellipsoid joint
  • ➤ allowing flexion
  • ➤ extension
  • ➤ side-to-side movements
  • ➤ Ref: Textbook of Anatomy Upper limb and Thorax Vishram Singh 3rd edition pg. 153
  • ➤ Ref: Textbook of Anatomy Upper limb and Thorax Vishram Singh 3rd edition pg. 153

questions.text: A patient presents with a sprained ankle following a sports injury. Which type of connective tissue structure is most commonly affected in ankle sprains?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Ligaments

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Aponeuroses - They are flat , broad tendinous sheets . They serve as a means for muscle attachment to the bones but are not directly involved in connecting bones at a joint .
  • • Option A. Aponeuroses -
  • • flat
  • • broad tendinous sheets
  • • muscle attachment
  • • bones
  • • .
  • • Option B. Tendon - They are strong , fibrous connective tissues that connect muscles to bones . They help in transmitting the force generated by muscles to bones, causing movement .
  • • Option B. Tendon -
  • • strong
  • • fibrous connective tissues
  • • connect muscles
  • • bones
  • • transmitting the force
  • • movement
  • • Option C. Fasciculi - It refers to bundles of muscle fibers within a muscle. They are part of the muscle's internal structure and are involved in muscle contraction and force generation .
  • • Option C. Fasciculi -
  • • bundles of muscle fibers
  • • muscle's internal structure
  • • involved
  • • muscle contraction
  • • force generation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ligaments are tough bands of fibrous connective tissue . They connect bones to other bones at a joint, providing stability and guiding joint movement .
  • ➤ tough bands
  • ➤ fibrous connective tissue
  • ➤ connect bones
  • ➤ providing stability
  • ➤ guiding joint movement
  • ➤ Ref: Textbook of General Anatomy, 3 rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 18
  • ➤ Ref:
  • ➤ Textbook of General Anatomy, 3 rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 18

questions.text: Which type of joint is characterized by the presence of a cartilaginous pad or disc between the articulating bones and allows for limited movement?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Secondary Cartilaginous Joint

  • • Option A. Suture joints are fibrous joints found in the skull , where the bones are tightly interlocked and allow for no movement.

  • • synovial fluid
  • • allow
  • • wide range of movements
  • • Option D. Fibrous joints, such as sutures or syndesmoses, are characterized by dense fibrous connective tissue and do not allow significant movement.
  • • Option D.
  • • dense fibrous connective tissue

questions.text: Which type of joint is characterized by the presence of fibrous connective tissue that tightly holds adjacent cranial bones together, allowing minimal to no movement?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Sutural Joint.

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Synovial joints, like the knee or shoulder joint, have a synovial cavity filled with synovial fluid and allow for a wide range of movements .

questions.text: Which type of joint allows for rotational movement of the forearm, specifically allowing pronation and supination?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Pivot Joint

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Hinge joints, such as the elbow joint , permit movement primarily in one plane (flexion and extension) and do not allow for the rotational movement seen in pronation and supination.

  • • elbow joint

  • • Option B. Ball-and-socket joints, like the hip joint , allow for a wide range of motion in multiple planes and are not involved in the specific rotational movements of the middle radioulnar joint.
  • • Option B.
  • • hip joint
  • • wide range of motion
  • • multiple planes
  • • Option D. Saddle joints, such as the carpometacarpal joint of the thumb, allow for movements in multiple directions , including flexion, extension, abduction, adduction , and circumduction , but they do not primarily facilitate pronation and supination.
  • • Option D.
  • • carpometacarpal joint
  • • movements in multiple directions
  • • flexion, extension, abduction, adduction
  • • circumduction

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Match the following according to the classification of arrangement of muscle fibres with their example for each type?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 1- b, 2- a, 3- d, 4- c

Explanation:

  • • Explanation: Different types of arrangement of muscle fibres shown in image:
  • • 1. Parallel Arrangement:
  • • 1. Parallel Arrangement:
  • • Muscle fibers run parallel to the long axis of the muscle. Example: Biceps brachii
  • • Muscle fibers run parallel to the long axis of the muscle.
  • • parallel
  • • long axis
  • • Example: Biceps brachii
  • • Example: Biceps brachii
  • • 2. Pennate Arrangement:
  • • 2. Pennate Arrangement:
  • • Muscle Fibers are obliquely oriented to the tendon , forming a feather-like pattern . Example: Rectus Femoris
  • • Muscle Fibers are obliquely oriented to the tendon , forming a feather-like pattern .
  • • obliquely
  • • tendon
  • • feather-like pattern
  • • Example: Rectus Femoris
  • • Example: Rectus Femoris
  • • 3. Cruciate Arrangement:
  • • 3. Cruciate Arrangement:
  • • Muscle fibres having 2 sets , which cross each other Example: Sternocleidomastoid
  • • Muscle fibres having 2 sets , which cross each other
  • • 2 sets
  • • cross each other
  • • Example: Sternocleidomastoid
  • • Example: Sternocleidomastoid
  • • 4. Spiral/ Twisted:
  • • 4. Spiral/ Twisted:
  • • Muscle fibres having only 1 set in which upper fibres runs down & lower fibres runs upside in between attachments . Example: Latissimus Dorsi & Pectoralis Major
  • • Muscle fibres having only 1 set in which upper fibres runs down & lower fibres runs upside in between attachments .
  • • only 1 set
  • • upper fibres runs down

  • ➤ Arrangement of muscle fibre direction - Biceps brachii shows Parallel arrangement, Rectus femoris shows Pennate arrangement, Sternocleidomastoid shows Cruciate arrangement & Latissimus dorsi shows Spiral arrangement.
  • ➤ Arrangement of muscle fibre direction - Biceps brachii shows Parallel arrangement, Rectus femoris shows Pennate arrangement, Sternocleidomastoid shows Cruciate arrangement & Latissimus dorsi shows Spiral arrangement.

  • ➤ Ref: Textbook of General Anatomy, 3 rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 123

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the classification of muscle fibre arrangement known as "Pennate Arrangement"?

options.label: A
options.text: Muscle Fibers run parallel to the long axis of the muscle.

options.label: B
options.text: Muscle Fibers are obliquely oriented to the tendon, forming a feather-like pattern.

options.label: C
options.text: Muscle Fibers encircle an opening or body cavity.

options.label: D
options.text: Muscle Fibers are arranged in a concentric circular pattern.

questions.correct_answer: B. Muscle Fibers are obliquely oriented to the tendon, forming a feather-like pattern.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Muscle fibers are obliquely oriented to the tendon, forming a feather-like pattern.

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • " Pennate Arrangement " refers to muscle fibers that are obliquely oriented to the tendon , creating a feather-like or fan-like pattern . This arrangement provides a greater number of muscle fibers in a given cross-sectional area , allowing for more force generation .
  • • " Pennate Arrangement " refers to muscle fibers that are obliquely oriented to the tendon , creating a feather-like or fan-like pattern .
  • • Pennate Arrangement
  • • muscle fibers
  • • obliquely oriented
  • • tendon
  • • feather-like
  • • fan-like pattern
  • • This arrangement provides a greater number of muscle fibers in a given cross-sectional area , allowing for more force generation .
  • • greater number
  • • muscle fibers
  • • cross-sectional area
  • • allowing
  • • force generation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The classification of "Pennate Arrangement" in Muscle Fibers involves Oblique orientation of fibers to the tendon , as seen in muscles like the Rectus Femoris.
  • ➤ involves Oblique orientation of fibers to the tendon
  • ➤ Ref: Textbook of General Anatomy, 3 rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 123
  • ➤ Ref: Textbook of General Anatomy, 3 rd edition, Vishram Singh, pg. 123

questions.text: Which of the following best describes a muscle with a "Strap-like with Tendinous intersections" Fiber Arrangement, characterized by Uniform Width and Parallel Fibers?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Rectus Abdominis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B:
  • • Option B:
  • • A " Strap-like" muscle , such as the Rectus Abdominis, is characterized by Uniform Width and Parallel muscle fibers running along the long axis of the muscle. The rectus abdominis is a prominent abdominal muscle that provides stability and support to the anterior abdominal wall . Its strap-like arrangement is well-suited for maintaining abdominal posture and assisting in various movements such as trunk flexion and stabilization . It is having ribbon like parallel arrangement and also in between tendinous intersections as shown in image:

questions.text: What is the typical fiber arrangement of lumbrical muscles in the hand?

options.label: A
options.text: 1 st & 2 nd Lumbricals – Unipennate, 3 rd & 4 th Lumbricals - Bipennate

options.label: B
options.text: 1 st & 2 nd Lumbricals – Biipennate, 3 rd & 4 th Lumbricals - Unipennate

options.label: C
options.text: 1 st & 3 rd Lumbricals – Biipennate, 2 nd & 4 th Lumbricals - Unipennate

options.label: D
options.text: 2 nd & 3 rd Lumbricals – Biipennate, 1 st & 4 th Lumbricals - Unipennate

questions.correct_answer: A. 1 st & 2 nd Lumbricals – Unipennate, 3 rd & 4 th Lumbricals - Bipennate
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 1st& 2ndLumbricals – Unipennate, 3rd& 4thLumbricals - Bipennate

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option B. 1 st & 2 nd Lumbricals – Biipennate, 3 rd & 4 th Lumbricals – Unipennate: It is just opposite of nature of lumbricals hence it is not the answer .
  • • Option B. 1 st & 2 nd Lumbricals – Biipennate, 3 rd & 4 th Lumbricals – Unipennate:
  • • not the answer
  • • Option C. 1 st & 3 rd Lumbricals – Biipennate, 2 nd & 4 th Lumbricals – Unipennate: It is also not matching according to direction of muscle fibres of lumbricals.
  • • Option C. 1 st & 3 rd Lumbricals – Biipennate, 2 nd & 4 th Lumbricals – Unipennate:
  • • also not matching
  • • Option D. It is indicating that 2 nd & 3 rd Lumbricals – Biipennate, 1 st & 4 th Lumbricals – Unipennate which is also incorrect .
  • • Option D. It is indicating that 2 nd & 3 rd Lumbricals – Biipennate, 1 st & 4 th Lumbricals –
  • • also incorrect

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ 1 st & 2 nd Lumbrical muscles in the hand typically exhibit a "Unipennate" arrangement , while 3 rd & 4 th Lumbrical muscles shows "Bipennate" arrangement . It is very important group of muscle because it is responsible for proper gripping by fingers & hand .
  • ➤ 1 st & 2 nd Lumbrical muscles in the hand typically exhibit a "Unipennate" arrangement , while 3 rd & 4 th Lumbrical muscles shows "Bipennate" arrangement .

  • ➤ "Bipennate" arrangement
  • ➤ It is very important group of muscle because it is responsible for proper gripping by fingers & hand .
